newsitem.title: ISRAEL: U.S. envoy struggles to revive Israeli-PLO talks.
newsitem.headline: U.S. envoy struggles to revive Israeli-PLO talks.

text.p: U.S. Middle East envoy Dennis Ross struggled on Thursday to put Israeli-PLO peace talks back on track despite tough stands by both sides on a Jewish settlement under construction in Arab East Jerusalem.

Ross, on his second rescue mission in a month, held three hours of talks with Palestinian President Yasser Arafat in Gaza following two sessions on Wednesday and Thursday with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
Officials gave no details about the talks but said Ross would see Netanyahu later on Thursday and meet Arafat again in the West Bank town of Ramallah on Friday.
"There are difficult problems that have to be overcome but we all realise the importance of trying to find ways to move forward," Ross told reporters in Gaza after the meeting.
"I've seen the chairman. We had a good discussion and I will see him again after seeing the prime minister. I will try to find ways and means to overcome the difficulties that exist," he said.
Israeli-PLO peace talks broke down two months ago after Netanyahu gave the final go-ahead to build 6,500 houses for Jews on a West Bank hilltop which Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East war.
Arafat spokesman Marwan Kanafani said the Palestinian leader stressed to Ross the need to stop all settlement activity before peace talks could resume.
"We don't know if Mr Ross will come with an answer to our grievences and our worries," Kanafani said.

"But we hope that Mr Ross will understand that nothing can be moved without stopping Israeli settlement activities. This is not only illegal and an obstacle to peace. This is a suicide to the peace process in its entirety," he said.
Earlier on Thursday, the secretary-general of the Palestinian Authority said Israel's suspension of work on the new settlement was a condition for resuming peace talks.
Ahmed Abdel-Rahman said that settlement activity was carving up the West Bank into enclaves and making it impossible for Palestinians to establish an independent state.
Netanyahu's aide David Bar-Illan said the work would continue.
"We obviously are not going to stop building in the settlements any more than the Palestinians are going to stop building in their towns," he said on Wednesday.
Israel demands the Palestinian Authority crack down on "terror" before resuming talks.
Israeli and Palestinian officials have played down any expectation of a breakthrough during Ross's mission.

Palestinians have rejected Israel's offer to build housing for East Jerusalem Palestinians and to discuss speeding up talks on building a seaport and opening an airport in Gaza as part of a compromise to revive peace talks.
